title: Understanding Gibbs Free Energy Relation
text:
The Gibbs free energy change of a reaction (∆G°) is given by the relation: $$∆G\degree=$$ ∆H°- T × ∆S°.

- ∆H° is the change in enthalpy.
- T is the temperature in Kelvin.
- ∆S° is the change in entropy.

title: Identify the Values
text:
You are given:
- ∆G° $$=$$ $$110.5$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$
- Temperature (T) $$=$$ $$298$$ K

You need to find ∆S°. Known substances' enthalpies of formation:
- CO(g): $$-110.5$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$
- $$H_2 O\left(gight)$$: $$-241.8$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$

Assume that ∆H° is derived from the sum of formation enthalpies of products minus reactants.

title: Calculate the Enthalpy Change (∆H°)
text: Use the enthalpy of formation values to determine ∆H° for the reaction:\n\n∆H° $$=$$ ∆H°_f (CO(g)) + ∆H°_f $$\operatorname{H_2}\left(g\right)$$ - [∆H°_f (C(s)) + ∆H°_f (H_2O(g))]

title: Substitute into Gibbs Free Energy Equation
text: Now that you have ∆H° and ∆G°, substitute these into the Gibbs free energy equation to solve for ∆S°:\n\n$$110.5$$ $$=$$ $$131.3$$ - $$298$$ × ∆S°

title: Solve for ∆S°
text: Rearrange the equation and solve for ∆S° in $$\frac{J}{mol}$$ *K:\n\n∆S° $$=$$ (∆H° - ∆G°) / T
